Name: Issue 308
Summary: Communities, WWDC Notes, and a Weekly Xamarin App.
Introduction: It's almost the weekend and that means it's time for the Weekly Xamarin newsletter.  As always lots of great articles for the week. I particularly like the WWDC roundup and the List of World  Wide Xamarin & MAUI communities that Luis Matos has curated.  We are also pleased to announce we now have a Weekly Xamarin App.  It's a little rough around the edges, but hope you find it useful.  [Check it out here.](https://weeklyxamarin.github.io/website/) Thanks to the wonderful people who have made this happen: Lachlan Gordon, Luce Carter, Ryan Davis, David Wahid, James Montemagno, Aden Earnshaw, Sameer Mansoor and Jonathan Parker (and many others who have watched the streams of us building it).  If you want to contribute and help build it out further we accept pull requests ;-) Have a great weekend everyone. ❤ Kym

Articles.Title: Getting Started with Dependency Injection in Xamarin.Forms
Articles.Description: What do you do when you want to create testable code or when you need to access native features? You need an interface to implement! Then you need a way to inject that implementation (dependency) to access it from your shared code (or anywhere). You will do this pretty often with mobile application development and luckily for us Xamarin.Forms has it all built in! Today' we take a look at Dependency Injection for Xamarin.Forms to create testable services and also access native features.
Articles.Author: James Montemagno

Articles.Title: Setup Maps in Your Xamarin.Forms Apps
Articles.Description: Learn how to add Xamarin.Forms.Maps to your app and use maps in your Xamarin.Forms app! In this video we will see how to add a map to your iOS and Android app. We will add permissions, API keys and all the things that are needed to show that map on screen. I know there were request for other things with maps, let me know in the comments what you'd like to see next!
